questions.question: Which of the following is part of the Basis and Purpose of the Amateur Radio Service?

choices.A: Providing personal radio communications for as many citizens as possible
choices.B: Providing communications for international non-profit organizations
choices.C: Advancing skills in the technical and communication phases of the radio art

questions.question: Which agency regulates and enforces the rules for the Amateur Radio Service in the United States?
What do the FCC rules state regarding the use of a phonetic alphabet for station identification in the Amateur Radio Service?

choices.A: It is required when transmitting emergency messages
choices.C: It is required when in contact with foreign stations

questions.question: How many operator/primary station license grants may be held by any one person?

choices.C: One for each band on which the person plans to operate
choices.D: One for each permanent station location from which the person plans to operate

questions.question: What proves that the FCC has issued an operator/primary license grant?

choices.A: A printed copy of the certificate of successful completion of examination
choices.B: An email notification from the NCVEC granting the license
choices.C: The license appears in the FCC ULS database

questions.question: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a beacon?

choices.A: A government transmitter marking the amateur radio band edges
choices.B: A bulletin sent by the FCC to announce a national emergency
choices.C: A continuous transmission of weather information authorized in the amateur bands by the National Weather Service
choices.D: An amateur station transmitting communications for the purposes of observing propagation or related experimental activities

questions.question: What is the FCC Part 97 definition of a space station?

choices.C: An amateur station located more than 50 km above Earth's surface
choices.D: An amateur station using amateur radio satellites for relay of signals

questions.question: Which of the following entities recommends transmit/receive channels and other parameters for auxiliary and repeater stations?

choices.A: Frequency Spectrum Manager appointed by the FCC
choices.B: Volunteer Frequency Coordinator recognized by local amateurs

questions.question: Who selects a Frequency Coordinator?

choices.A: The FCC Office of Spectrum Management and Coordination Policy
choices.B: The local chapter of the Office of National Council of Independent Frequency Coordinators
choices.C: Amateur operators in a local or regional area whose stations are eligible to be repeater or auxiliary stations

questions.question: What is the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service (RACES)?

choices.A: A radio service using amateur frequencies for emergency management or civil defense communications
choices.B: A radio service using amateur stations for emergency management or civil defense communications
choices.C: An emergency service using amateur operators certified by a civil defense organization as being enrolled in that organization

questions.question: When is willful interference to other amateur radio stations permitted?

choices.A: To stop another amateur station that is breaking the FCC rules
choices.D: At any time, stations in the Amateur Radio Service are not protected from willful interference

questions.question: Which of the following frequency ranges are available for phone operation by Technician licensees?
Which amateurs may contact the International Space Station (ISS) on VHF bands?

choices.A: Any amateur holding a General class or higher license
choices.B: Any amateur holding a Technician class or higher license
choices.C: Any amateur holding a General class or higher license who has applied for and received approval from NASA
choices.D: Any amateur holding a Technician class or higher license who has applied for and received approval from NASA

questions.question: Which frequency is in the 6 meter amateur band?
Which amateur band includes 146.52 MHz?
How may amateurs use the 219 to 220 MHz segment of 1.25 meter band?

choices.D: Fixed digital message forwarding systems only

questions.question: On which HF bands does a Technician class operator have phone privileges?

choices.C: 80 meter, 40 meter, 15 meter, and 10 meter bands

questions.question: Which of the following VHF/UHF band segments are limited to CW only?

choices.A: 50.0 MHz to 50.1 MHz and 144.0 MHz to 144.1 MHz
choices.B: 219 MHz to 220 MHz and 420.0 MHz to 420.1 MHz

questions.question: How are US amateurs restricted in segments of bands where the Amateur Radio Service is secondary?

choices.A: U.S. amateurs may find non-amateur stations in those segments, and must avoid interfering with them
choices.B: U.S. amateurs must give foreign amateur stations priority in those segments
choices.C: International communications are not permitted in those segments
choices.D: Digital transmissions are not permitted in those segments

questions.question: Why should you not set your transmit frequency to be exactly at the edge of an amateur band or sub-band?

choices.A: To allow for calibration error in the transmitter frequency display
choices.B: So that modulation sidebands do not extend beyond the band edge
choices.C: To allow for transmitter frequency drift

questions.question: Where may SSB phone be used in amateur bands above 50 MHz?

choices.A: Only in sub-bands allocated to General class or higher licensees
choices.C: In at least some segment of all these bands
choices.D: On any band if the power is limited to 25 watts

questions.question: What is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators in their HF band segments?
Except for some specific restrictions, what is the maximum peak envelope power output for Technician class operators using frequencies above 30 MHz?
For which license classes are new licenses currently available from the FCC?

choices.B: Technician, Technician Plus, General, Amateur Extra

questions.question: Who may select a desired call sign under the vanity call sign rules?

choices.A: Only a licensed amateur with a General or Amateur Extra Class license
choices.B: Only a licensed amateur with an Amateur Extra Class license
choices.C: Only a licensed amateur who has been licensed continuously for more than 10 years

questions.question: What types of international communications are an FCC-licensed amateur radio station permitted to make?

choices.A: Communications incidental to the purposes of the Amateur Radio Service and remarks of a personal character
choices.B: Communications incidental to conducting business or remarks of a personal nature
choices.C: Only communications incidental to contest exchanges; all other communications are prohibited
choices.D: Any communications that would be permitted by an international broadcast station

questions.question: What may happen if the FCC is unable to reach you by email?

choices.A: Fine and suspension of operator license
choices.B: Revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license
choices.C: Revocation of access to the license record in the FCC system
choices.D: Nothing; there is no such requirement

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid Technician class call sign format?
From which of the following locations may an FCC-licensed amateur station transmit?

choices.A: From within any country that belongs to the International Telecommunication Union
choices.B: From within any country that is a member of the United Nations
choices.C: From anywhere within International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Regions 2 and 3
choices.D: From any vessel or craft located in international waters and documented or registered in the United States

questions.question: Which of the following can result in revocation of the station license or suspension of the operator license?

choices.A: Failure to inform the FCC of any changes in the amateur station following performance of an RF safety environmental evaluation
choices.B: Failure to provide and maintain a correct email address with the FCC
choices.C: Failure to obtain FCC type acceptance prior to using a home-built transmitter
choices.D: Failure to have a copy of your license available at your station

questions.question: What is the normal term for an FCC-issued amateur radio license?
What is the grace period for renewal if an amateur license expires?
How soon after passing the examination for your first amateur radio license may you transmit on the amateur radio bands?

choices.A: Immediately on receiving your Certificate of Successful Completion of Examination (CSCE)
choices.B: As soon as your operator/station license grant appears on the ARRL website
choices.C: As soon as your operator/station license grant appears in the FCC’s license database
choices.D: As soon as you receive your license in the mail from the FCC

questions.question: If your license has expired and is still within the allowable grace period, may you continue to transmit on the amateur radio bands?

choices.A: Yes, for up to two years
choices.B: Yes, as soon as you apply for renewal
choices.C: Yes, for up to one year
choices.D: No, you must wait until the license has been renewed

questions.question: With which countries are FCC-licensed amateur radio stations prohibited from exchanging communications?

choices.A: Any country whose administration has notified the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) that it objects to such communications
choices.B: Any country whose administration has notified the American Radio Relay League (ARRL) that it objects to such communications
choices.C: Any country banned from such communications by the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU)
choices.D: Any country banned from making such communications by the American Radio Relay League (ARRL)

questions.question: Under which of the following circumstances are one-way transmissions by an amateur station prohibited?
When is it permissible to transmit messages encoded to obscure their meaning?

choices.B: Only when transmitting certain approved digital codes
choices.C: Only when transmitting control commands to space stations or radio control craft

questions.question: Under what conditions is an amateur station authorized to transmit music using a phone emission?

choices.A: When incidental to an authorized retransmission of manned spacecraft communications
choices.B: When the music produces no spurious emissions
choices.C: When transmissions are limited to less than three minutes per hour
choices.D: When the music is transmitted above 1280 MHz

questions.question: When may amateur radio operators use their stations to notify other amateurs of the availability of equipment for sale or trade?

choices.B: When the equipment is not the personal property of either the station licensee, or the control operator, or their close relatives
choices.C: When no profit is made on the sale
choices.D: When selling amateur radio equipment and not on a regular basis

questions.question: What, if any, are the restrictions concerning transmission of language that may be considered indecent or obscene?

choices.A: The FCC maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies
choices.C: The ITU maintains a list of words that are not permitted to be used on amateur frequencies

questions.question: What types of amateur stations can automatically retransmit the signals of other amateur stations?
In which of the following circumstances may the control operator of an amateur station receive compensation for operating that station?

choices.A: When the communication is related to the sale of amateur equipment by the control operator's employer
choices.B: When the communication is incidental to classroom instruction at an educational institution
choices.C: When the communication is made to obtain emergency information for a local broadcast station

questions.question: When may amateur stations transmit information in support of broadcasting, program production, or news gathering, assuming no other means is available?

choices.A: When such communications are directly related to the immediate safety of human life or protection of property
choices.B: When broadcasting communications to or from the space shuttle
choices.C: Where noncommercial programming is gathered and supplied exclusively to the National Public Radio network

questions.question: How does the FCC define broadcasting for the Amateur Radio Service?

choices.B: Any transmission made by the licensed station
choices.C: Transmission of messages directed only to amateur operators
choices.D: Transmissions intended for reception by the general public

questions.question: When may an amateur station transmit without identifying on the air?

choices.A: When the transmissions are of a brief nature to make station adjustments
choices.C: When the transmitted power level is below 1 watt
choices.D: When transmitting signals to control model craft

questions.question: When may an amateur station transmit without a control operator?

choices.A: When using automatic control, such as in the case of a repeater
choices.B: When the station licensee is away and another licensed amateur is using the station
choices.C: When the transmitting station is an auxiliary station

questions.question: Who may be the control operator of a station communicating through an amateur satellite or space station?

choices.A: Only an Amateur Extra Class operator
choices.B: A General class or higher licensee with a satellite operator certification
choices.C: Only an Amateur Extra Class operator who is also an AMSAT member
choices.D: Any amateur allowed to transmit on the satellite uplink frequency

questions.question: Who must designate the station control operator?
What determines the transmitting frequency privileges of an amateur station?

choices.A: The frequency authorized by the frequency coordinator
choices.B: The frequencies printed on the license grant
choices.C: The highest class of operator license held by anyone on the premises
choices.D: The class of operator license held by the control operator

questions.question: What is an amateur station’s control point?

choices.A: The location of the station’s transmitting antenna
choices.B: The location of the station’s transmitting apparatus
choices.C: The location at which the control operator function is performed
choices.D: The mailing address of the station licensee

questions.question: When, under normal circumstances, may a Technician class licensee be the control operator of a station operating in an Amateur Extra Class band segment?

choices.B: When designated as the control operator by an Amateur Extra Class licensee
choices.C: As part of a multi-operator contest team
choices.D: When using a club station whose trustee holds an Amateur Extra Class license

questions.question: When the control operator is not the station licensee, who is responsible for the proper operation of the station?

choices.A: All licensed amateurs who are present at the operation
choices.D: The control operator and the station licensee

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of automatic control?

choices.B: Controlling a station over the internet
choices.C: Using a computer or other device to send CW automatically
choices.D: Using a computer or other device to identify automatically

questions.question: Which of the following are required for remote control operation?

choices.A: The control operator must be at the control point
choices.B: A control operator is required at all times
choices.C: The control operator must indirectly manipulate the controls

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of remote control as defined in Part 97?

choices.B: Operating the station over the internet
choices.C: Controlling a model aircraft, boat, or car by amateur radio

questions.question: Who does the FCC presume to be the control operator of an amateur station, unless documentation to the contrary is in the station records?

choices.C: The person operating the station equipment

sections.section_title: Topics on FCC Regulations and Amateur License

questions.question: When must the station and its records be available for FCC inspection?

choices.A: At any time ten days after notification by the FCC of such an inspection
choices.B: At any time upon request by an FCC representative
choices.C: At any time after written notification by the FCC of such inspection
choices.D: Only when presented with a valid warrant by an FCC official or government agent

questions.question: How often must you identify with your FCC-assigned call sign when using tactical call signs such as “Race Headquarters”?

choices.A: Never, the tactical call is sufficient
choices.C: At the end of each communication and every ten minutes during a communication
choices.D: At the end of every transmission

questions.question: When are you required to transmit your assigned call sign?

choices.A: At the beginning of each contact, and every 10 minutes thereafter
choices.B: At least once during each transmission
choices.C: At least every 15 minutes during and at the end of a communication
choices.D: At least every 10 minutes during and at the end of a communication

questions.question: What language may you use for identification when operating in a phone sub-band?

choices.A: Any language recognized by the United Nations
choices.B: Any language recognized by the ITU

questions.question: What method of call sign identification is required for a station transmitting phone signals?

choices.A: Send the call sign followed by the indicator RPT
choices.B: Send the call sign using a CW or phone emission
choices.C: Send the call sign followed by the indicator R
choices.D: Send the call sign using only a phone emission

questions.question: Which of the following self-assigned indicators are acceptable when using a phone transmission?
Which of the following restrictions apply when a non-licensed person is allowed to speak to a foreign station using a station under the control of a licensed amateur operator?

choices.A: The person must be a U.S. citizen
choices.B: The foreign station must be in a country with which the U.S. has a third party agreement
choices.C: The licensed control operator must do the station identification

questions.question: What is the definition of third party communications?

choices.A: A message from a control operator to another amateur station control operator on behalf of another person
choices.B: Amateur radio communications where three stations are in communications with one another
choices.C: Operation when the transmitting equipment is licensed to a person other than the control operator
choices.D: Temporary authorization for an unlicensed person to transmit on the amateur bands for technical experiments

questions.question: What type of amateur station simultaneously retransmits the signal of another amateur station on a different channel or channels?
Who is accountable if a repeater inadvertently retransmits communications that violate the FCC rules?

choices.A: The control operator of the originating station
choices.B: The control operator of the repeater
choices.D: Both the originating station and the repeater owner

questions.question: Which of the following is a requirement for the issuance of a club station license grant?

choices.A: The trustee must have an Amateur Extra Class operator license grant
choices.B: The club must have at least four members
choices.C: The club must be registered with the American Radio Relay League

questions.question: What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 2 meter band?
What is the national calling frequency for FM simplex operations in the 2 meter band?
What is a common repeater frequency offset in the 70 cm band?
What is an appropriate way to call another station on a repeater if you know the other station's call sign?

choices.A: Say "break, break," then say the station's call sign
choices.B: Say the station's call sign, then identify with your call sign
choices.C: Say "CQ" three times, then the other station's call sign
choices.D: Wait for the station to call CQ, then answer

questions.question: How should you respond to a station calling CQ?

choices.A: Transmit "CQ" followed by the other station’s call sign
choices.B: Transmit your call sign followed by the other station’s call sign
choices.C: Transmit the other station’s call sign followed by your call sign
choices.D: Transmit a signal report followed by your call sign

questions.question: Which of the following is required when making on-the-air test transmissions?

choices.B: Conduct tests only between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. local time
choices.C: Notify the FCC of the transmissions

questions.question: What is meant by "repeater offset”?

choices.A: The difference between a repeater’s transmit and receive frequencies
choices.B: The repeater has a time delay to prevent interference
choices.C: The repeater station identification is done on a separate frequency
choices.D: The number of simultaneous transmit frequencies used by a repeater

questions.question: What is the meaning of the procedural signal “CQ”?

choices.C: Only the called station should transmit

questions.question: Which of the following indicates that a station is listening on a repeater and looking for a contact?

choices.A: “CQ CQ” followed by the repeater’s call sign
choices.B: The station’s call sign followed by the word “monitoring”
choices.C: The repeater call sign followed by the station’s call sign

questions.question: What is a band plan, beyond the privileges established by the FCC?

choices.A: A voluntary guideline for using different modes or activities within an amateur band
choices.C: A list of available net frequencies
choices.D: A plan devised by a club to indicate frequency band usage

questions.question: What term describes an amateur station that is transmitting and receiving on the same frequency?
What should you do before calling CQ?

choices.A: Listen first to be sure that no one else is using the frequency
choices.B: Ask if the frequency is in use
choices.C: Make sure you are authorized to use that frequency

questions.question: How is a VHF/UHF transceiver’s “reverse” function used?

choices.C: To listen on a repeater’s input frequency
choices.D: To listen on a repeater’s output frequency

questions.question: What term describes the use of a sub-audible tone transmitted along with normal voice audio to open the squelch of a receiver?
Which of the following describes a linked repeater network?

choices.A: A network of repeaters in which signals received by one repeater are transmitted by all the repeaters in the network
choices.B: A single repeater with more than one receiver
choices.C: Multiple repeaters with the same control operator
choices.D: A system of repeaters linked by APRS

questions.question: Which of the following could be the reason you are unable to access a repeater whose output you can hear?

choices.B: You are using the wrong CTCSS tone
choices.C: You are using the wrong DCS code

questions.question: What would cause your FM transmission audio to be distorted on voice peaks?

choices.D: Your transmit power is too high

questions.question: What type of signaling uses pairs of audio tones?
How can you join a digital repeater’s “talkgroup”?

choices.A: Register your radio with the local FCC office
choices.C: Program your radio with the group’s ID or code
choices.D: Sign your call after the courtesy tone

questions.question: Which of the following applies when two stations transmitting on the same frequency interfere with each other?

choices.A: The stations should negotiate continued use of the frequency
choices.B: Both stations should choose another frequency to avoid conflict
choices.C: Interference is inevitable, so no action is required
choices.D: Use subaudible tones so both stations can share the frequency

questions.question: Why are simplex channels designated in the VHF/UHF band plans?

choices.A: So stations within range of each other can communicate without tying up a repeater
choices.D: So stations with simple transmitters can access the repeater without automated offset

questions.question: Which Q signal indicates that you are receiving interference from other stations?
Which Q signal indicates that you are changing frequency?
What is the purpose of the color code used on DMR repeater systems?

choices.A: Must match the repeater color code for access
choices.B: Defines the frequency pair to use
choices.D: Defines the minimum signal level required for access

questions.question: What is the purpose of a squelch function?

choices.A: Reduce a CW transmitter's key clicks
choices.B: Mute the receiver audio when a signal is not present
choices.C: Eliminate parasitic oscillations in an RF amplifier

questions.question: When do FCC rules NOT apply to the operation of an amateur station?

choices.B: When operating under special FEMA rules
choices.C: When operating under special ARES rules

questions.question: Which of the following are typical duties of a Net Control Station?

choices.A: Choose the regular net meeting time and frequency
choices.B: Ensure that all stations checking into the net are properly licensed for operation on the net frequency
choices.C: Call the net to order and direct communications between stations checking in

questions.question: What technique is used to ensure that voice messages containing unusual words are received correctly?

choices.A: Send the words by voice and Morse code
choices.B: Speak very loudly into the microphone
choices.C: Spell the words using a standard phonetic alphabet

questions.question: What is RACES?

choices.A: An emergency organization combining amateur radio and citizens band operators and frequencies
choices.C: A radio contest held in a short period, sometimes called a “sprint”
choices.D: An FCC part 97 amateur radio service for civil defense communications during national emergencies

questions.question: What does the term “traffic” refer to in net operation?

choices.B: The number of stations checking in and out of a net
choices.C: Operation by mobile or portable stations
choices.D: Requests to activate the net by a served agency

questions.question: What is the Amateur Radio Emergency Service (ARES)?

choices.A: A group of licensed amateurs who have voluntarily registered their qualifications and equipment for communications duty in the public service
choices.B: A group of licensed amateurs who are members of the military and who voluntarily agreed to provide message handling services in the case of an emergency
choices.C: A training program that provides licensing courses for those interested in obtaining an amateur license to use during emergencies
choices.D: A training program that certifies amateur operators for membership in the Radio Amateur Civil Emergency Service

questions.question: Which of the following is standard practice when you participate in a net?

choices.A: When first responding to the net control station, transmit your call sign, name, and address as in the FCC database
choices.B: Record the time of each of your transmissions
choices.C: Unless you are reporting an emergency, transmit only when directed by the net control station

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of good traffic handling?

choices.B: Making decisions as to whether messages are worthy of relay or delivery
choices.C: Ensuring that any newsworthy messages are relayed to the news media

questions.question: Are amateur station control operators ever permitted to operate outside the frequency privileges of their license class?

choices.B: Yes, but only when part of a FEMA emergency plan
choices.C: Yes, but only when part of a RACES emergency plan
choices.D: Yes, but only in situations involving the immediate safety of human life or protection of property

questions.question: What information is contained in the preamble of a formal traffic message?

choices.A: The email address of the originating station
choices.B: The address of the intended recipient
choices.C: The telephone number of the addressee
choices.D: Information needed to track the message

questions.question: What is meant by “check” in a radiogram header?

choices.A: The number of words or word equivalents in the text portion of the message
choices.B: The call sign of the originating station
choices.C: A list of stations that have relayed the message
choices.D: A box on the message form that indicates that the message was received and/or relayed

questions.question: Why do VHF signal strengths sometimes vary greatly when the antenna is moved only a few feet?

choices.A: The signal path encounters different concentrations of water vapor
choices.B: VHF ionospheric propagation is very sensitive to path length
choices.C: Multipath propagation cancels or reinforces signals

questions.question: What is the effect of vegetation on UHF and microwave signals?
What antenna polarization is normally used for long-distance CW and SSB contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
What happens when antennas at opposite ends of a VHF or UHF line of sight radio link are not using the same polarization?

choices.A: The modulation sidebands might become inverted

questions.question: When using a directional antenna, how might your station be able to communicate with a distant repeater if buildings or obstructions are blocking the direct line of sight path?

choices.A: Change from vertical to horizontal polarization
choices.B: Try to find a path that reflects signals to the repeater

questions.question: What is the meaning of the term “picket fencing”?

choices.A: Alternating transmissions during a net operation
choices.B: Rapid flutter on mobile signals due to multipath propagation
choices.C: A type of ground system used with vertical antennas

questions.question: What weather condition might decrease range at microwave frequencies?
What is a likely cause of irregular fading of signals propagated by the ionosphere?

choices.A: Frequency shift due to Faraday rotation
choices.D: Random combining of signals arriving via different paths

questions.question: Which of the following results from the fact that signals propagated by the ionosphere are elliptically polarized?

choices.B: Either vertically or horizontally polarized antennas may be used for transmission or reception
choices.D: Both the transmitting and receiving antennas must be of the same polarization

questions.question: What effect does multi-path propagation have on data transmissions?

choices.A: Transmission rates must be increased by a factor equal to the number of separate paths observed
choices.B: Transmission rates must be decreased by a factor equal to the number of separate paths observed
choices.C: No significant changes will occur if the signals are transmitted using FM
choices.D: Error rates are likely to increase

questions.question: Which region of the atmosphere can refract or bend HF and VHF radio waves?
What is the effect of fog and rain on signals in the 10 meter and 6 meter bands?
What is the relationship between the electric and magnetic fields of an electromagnetic wave?
What property of a radio wave defines its polarization?

choices.A: The orientation of the electric field
choices.B: The orientation of the magnetic field
choices.C: The ratio of the energy in the magnetic field to the energy in the electric field
choices.D: The ratio of the velocity to the wavelength

questions.question: What are the two components of a radio wave?
What is the velocity of a radio wave traveling through free space?

choices.C: Speed inversely proportional to its wavelength
choices.D: Speed that increases as the frequency increases

questions.question: What is the relationship between wavelength and frequency?

choices.A: Wavelength gets longer as frequency increases
choices.B: Wavelength gets shorter as frequency increases
choices.D: Wavelength and frequency increase as path length increases

questions.question: What is the formula for converting frequency to approximate wavelength in meters?

choices.A: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in hertz multiplied by 300
choices.B: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in hertz divided by 300
choices.C: Wavelength in meters equals frequency in megahertz divided by 300
choices.D: Wavelength in meters equals 300 divided by frequency in megahertz

questions.question: In addition to frequency, which of the following is used to identify amateur radio bands?
What frequency range is referred to as VHF?
What frequency range is referred to as UHF?
What frequency range is referred to as HF?
What is the approximate velocity of a radio wave in free space?
Why are simplex UHF signals rarely heard beyond their radio horizon?

choices.A: They are too weak to go very far
choices.B: FCC regulations prohibit them from going more than 50 miles
choices.C: UHF signals are usually not propagated by the ionosphere
choices.D: UHF signals are absorbed by the ionospheric D region

questions.question: What is a characteristic of HF communication compared with communications on VHF and higher frequencies?

choices.C: Long-distance ionospheric propagation is far more common on HF
choices.D: There is less atmospheric interference (static) on HF

questions.question: What is a characteristic of VHF signals received via auroral backscatter?

choices.A: They are often received from 10,000 miles or more
choices.B: They are distorted and signal strength varies considerably
choices.C: They occur only during winter nighttime hours
choices.D: They are generally strongest when your antenna is aimed west

questions.question: Which of the following types of propagation is most commonly associated with occasional strong signals on the 10, 6, and 2 meter bands from beyond the radio horizon?
Which of the following effects may allow radio signals to travel beyond obstructions between the transmitting and receiving stations?
What type of propagation is responsible for allowing over-the-horizon VHF and UHF communications to ranges of approximately 300 miles on a regular basis?
What band is best suited for communicating via meteor scatter?
What causes tropospheric ducting?

choices.A: Discharges of lightning during electrical storms

questions.question: What is generally the best time for long-distance 10 meter band propagation via the F region?

choices.A: From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of high sunspot activity
choices.B: From shortly after sunset to dawn during periods of high sunspot activity
choices.C: From dawn to shortly after sunset during periods of low sunspot activity
choices.D: From shortly after sunset to dawn during periods of low sunspot activity

questions.question: Which of the following bands may provide long-distance communications via the ionosphere’s F region during the peak of the sunspot cycle?
Why is the radio horizon for VHF and UHF signals more distant than the visual horizon?

choices.A: Radio signals move somewhat faster than the speed of light
choices.B: Radio waves are not blocked by dust particles
choices.C: The atmosphere refracts radio waves slightly
choices.D: Radio waves are blocked by dust particles

questions.question: Which of the following is an appropriate power supply rating for a typical 50 watt output mobile FM transceiver?
Which of the following should be considered when selecting an accessory SWR meter?

choices.A: The frequency and power level at which the measurements will be made
choices.B: The distance that the meter will be located from the antenna
choices.C: The types of modulation being used at the station

questions.question: Why are short, heavy-gauge wires used for a transceiver’s DC power connection?

choices.A: To minimize voltage drop when transmitting
choices.B: To provide a good counterpoise for the antenna

questions.question: How are the transceiver audio input and output connected in a station configured to operate using FT8?

choices.A: To a computer running a terminal program and connected to a terminal node controller unit
choices.B: To the audio input and output of a computer running WSJT-X software
choices.C: To an FT8 conversion unit, a keyboard, and a computer monitor
choices.D: To a computer connected to the FT8converter.com website

questions.question: Where should an RF power meter be installed?

choices.A: In the feed line, between the transmitter and antenna
choices.C: In parallel with the push-to-talk line and the antenna
choices.D: In the power supply cable, as close as possible to the radio

questions.question: What signals are used in a computer-radio interface for digital mode operation?

choices.A: Receive and transmit mode, status, and location
choices.C: Receive audio, transmit audio, and transmitter keying
choices.D: NMEA GPS location and DC power

questions.question: Which of the following connections is made between a computer and a transceiver to use computer software when operating digital modes?

choices.C: Computer “line in” to transceiver speaker connector
choices.D: Computer “line out” to transceiver speaker connector

questions.question: Which of the following conductors is preferred for bonding at RF?

choices.A: Copper braid removed from coaxial cable

questions.question: How can you determine the length of time that equipment can be powered from a battery?

choices.A: Divide the watt-hour rating of the battery by the peak power consumption of the equipment
choices.B: Divide the battery ampere-hour rating by the average current draw of the equipment
choices.C: Multiply the watts per hour consumed by the equipment by the battery power rating
choices.D: Multiply the square of the current rating of the battery by the input resistance of the equipment

questions.question: What function is performed with a transceiver and a digital mode hot spot?

choices.A: Communication using digital voice or data systems via the internet
choices.C: RTTY encoding and decoding without a computer
choices.D: High-speed digital communications for meteor scatter

questions.question: Where should the negative power return of a mobile transceiver be connected in a vehicle?

choices.A: At the 12 volt battery chassis ground
choices.C: To any metal part of the vehicle

questions.question: What is an electronic keyer?

choices.A: A device for switching antennas from transmit to receive
choices.B: A device for voice activated switching from receive to transmit
choices.C: A device that assists in manual sending of Morse code
choices.D: An interlock to prevent unauthorized use of a radio

questions.question: What is the effect of excessive microphone gain on SSB transmissions?
Which of the following can be used to enter a transceiver’s operating frequency?
How is squelch adjusted so that a weak FM signal can be heard?

choices.A: Set the squelch threshold so that receiver output audio is on all the time
choices.B: Turn up the audio level until it overcomes the squelch threshold

questions.question: What is a way to enable quick access to a favorite frequency or channel on your transceiver?

choices.B: Store it in a memory channel
choices.D: Use the scan mode to select the desired frequency

questions.question: What does the scanning function of an FM transceiver do?

choices.C: Tunes through a range of frequencies to check for activity
choices.D: Checks for messages left on a digital bulletin board

questions.question: Which of the following controls could be used if the voice pitch of a single-sideband signal returning to your CQ call seems too high or low?
What does a DMR “code plug” contain?

choices.A: Your call sign in CW for automatic identification
choices.B: Access information for repeaters and talkgroups

questions.question: What is the advantage of having multiple receive bandwidth choices on a multimode transceiver?

choices.A: Permits monitoring several modes at once by selecting a separate filter for each mode
choices.B: Permits noise or interference reduction by selecting a bandwidth matching the mode
choices.C: Increases the number of frequencies that can be stored in memory
choices.D: Increases the amount of offset between receive and transmit frequencies

questions.question: How is a specific group of stations selected on a digital voice transceiver?

choices.A: By retrieving the frequencies from transceiver memory
choices.B: By enabling the group’s CTCSS tone
choices.C: By entering the group’s identification code

choices.B: Current that alternates between a negative direction and zero

choices.A: Radio frequency signals of all types

questions.question: What is the abbreviation for megahertz?

choices.A: The opposition to AC current flow

questions.question: What is the abbreviation for kilohertz?
What formula is used to calculate current in a circuit?

choices.A: A single circuit is opened or closed
choices.B: Two circuits are opened or closed
choices.C: A single circuit is switched between one of two other circuits
choices.D: Two circuits are each switched between one of two other circuits

questions.question: Which is true about forward voltage drop in a diode?

choices.A: It is lower in some diode types than in others
choices.B: It is proportional to peak inverse voltage
choices.C: It indicates that the diode is defective
choices.D: It has no impact on the voltage delivered to the load

questions.question: Which of the following displays an electrical quantity as a numeric value?

choices.A: Give off light when current flows through it

questions.question: Which of the following is a resonant or tuned circuit?

choices.A: An inductor and a capacitor in series or parallel
choices.C: A resistor circuit used for reducing standing wave ratio
choices.D: A circuit designed to provide high-fidelity audio

questions.question: Which term describes the ability of a receiver to detect the presence of a signal?
What is a transceiver?

choices.A: A device that combines a receiver and transmitter
choices.B: A device for matching feed line impedance to 50 ohms
choices.C: A device for automatically sending and decoding Morse code
choices.D: A device for converting receiver and transmitter frequencies to another band

questions.question: Which of the following is used to convert a signal from one frequency to another?
Which term describes the ability of a receiver to discriminate between multiple signals?
What is the name of a circuit that generates a signal at a specific frequency?
What device converts the RF input and output of a transceiver to another band?

choices.A: Input for a key used to send CW
choices.B: Switches transceiver from receive to transmit when grounded
choices.C: Provides a transmit tuning tone when grounded
choices.D: Input for a preamplifier tuning tone

questions.question: Which of the following describes combining speech with an RF carrier signal?

choices.A: Change the mode of the transmitted signal
choices.B: Set the amplifier for proper operation in the selected mode
choices.C: Change the frequency range of the amplifier to operate in the proper segment of the band

questions.question: What device increases the transmitted output power from a transceiver?
Where is an RF preamplifier installed?

choices.B: At the output of the transmitter power amplifier
choices.C: Between the transmitter and the antenna tuner
choices.D: At the output of the receiver audio amplifier

questions.question: What can you do if you are told your FM handheld or mobile transceiver is over-deviating?

choices.C: Change to a higher power level
choices.D: Talk farther away from the microphone

questions.question: What would cause a broadcast AM or FM radio to receive an amateur radio transmission unintentionally?

choices.A: The receiver is unable to reject strong signals outside the AM or FM band
choices.B: The microphone gain of the transmitter is turned up too high
choices.C: The audio amplifier of the transmitter is overloaded
choices.D: The deviation of an FM transmitter is set too low

questions.question: Which of the following can cause radio frequency interference?
Which of the following could you use to cure distorted audio caused by RF current on the shield of a microphone cable?
How can fundamental overload of a non-amateur radio or TV receiver by an amateur signal be reduced or eliminated?

choices.A: Block the amateur signal with a filter at the antenna input of the affected receiver
choices.B: Block the interfering signal with a filter on the amateur transmitter
choices.C: Switch the transmitter from FM to SSB
choices.D: Switch the transmitter to a narrow-band mode

questions.question: Which of the following actions should you take if a neighbor tells you that your station’s transmissions are interfering with their radio or TV reception?

choices.A: Make sure that your station is functioning properly and that it does not cause interference to your own radio or television when it is tuned to the same channel
choices.B: Immediately turn off your transmitter and contact the nearest FCC office for assistance
choices.C: Install a harmonic doubler on the output of your transmitter and tune it until the interference is eliminated

questions.question: Which of the following can reduce overload of a VHF transceiver by a nearby commercial FM station?

choices.C: Installing bypass capacitors on the microphone cable

questions.question: What should you do if something in a neighbor’s home is causing harmful interference to your amateur station?

choices.A: Work with your neighbor to identify the offending device
choices.B: Politely inform your neighbor that FCC rules prohibit the use of devices that cause interference
choices.C: Make sure your station meets the standards of good amateur practice

questions.question: What should be the first step to resolve non-fiber optic cable TV interference caused by your amateur radio transmission?

choices.A: Add a low-pass filter to the TV antenna input
choices.B: Add a high-pass filter to the TV antenna input
choices.C: Add a preamplifier to the TV antenna input
choices.D: Be sure all TV feed line coaxial connectors are installed properly

questions.question: What might be a problem if you receive a report that your audio signal through an FM repeater is distorted or unintelligible?

choices.A: Your transmitter is slightly off frequency
choices.C: You are in a bad location

questions.question: What is a symptom of RF feedback in a transmitter or transceiver?

choices.A: Excessive SWR at the antenna connection
choices.B: The transmitter will not stay on the desired frequency
choices.C: Reports of garbled, distorted, or unintelligible voice transmissions
choices.D: Frequent blowing of power supply fuses

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a dummy load?

choices.A: To prevent transmitting signals over the air when making tests
choices.B: To prevent over-modulation of a transmitter
choices.C: To improve the efficiency of an antenna
choices.D: To improve the signal-to-noise ratio of a receiver

questions.question: Which of the following is used to determine if an antenna is resonant at the desired operating frequency?
What does a dummy load consist of?

choices.A: A high-gain amplifier and a TR switch
choices.B: A non-inductive resistor mounted on a heat sink
choices.C: A low-voltage power supply and a DC relay
choices.D: A 50-ohm reactance used to terminate a transmission line

questions.question: What reading on an SWR meter indicates a perfect impedance match between the antenna and the feed line?
Why do most solid-state transmitters reduce output power as SWR increases beyond a certain level?

choices.A: To protect the output amplifier transistors
choices.B: To comply with FCC rules on spectral purity
choices.C: Because power supplies cannot supply enough current at high SWR
choices.D: To lower the SWR on the transmission line

questions.question: What does an SWR reading of 4:1 indicate?
What happens to power lost in a feed line?
Which instrument can be used to determine SWR?
Which of the following causes failure of coaxial cables?

choices.C: Rapid fluctuation in transmitter output power
choices.D: Operation at 100% duty cycle for an extended period

questions.question: Why should the outer jacket of coaxial cable be resistant to ultraviolet light?

choices.A: Ultraviolet resistant jackets prevent harmonic radiation
choices.B: Ultraviolet light can increase losses in the cable’s jacket
choices.C: Ultraviolet and RF signals can mix, causing interference
choices.D: Ultraviolet light can damage the jacket and allow water to enter the cable

questions.question: What is a disadvantage of air core coaxial cable when compared to foam or solid dielectric types?

choices.A: It has more loss per foot
choices.B: It cannot be used for VHF or UHF antennas
choices.C: It requires special techniques to prevent moisture in the cable
choices.D: It cannot be used at below freezing temperatures

questions.question: Which instrument would you use to measure electric potential?

When configured to measure current, how is a multimeter connected to a component?
Which instrument is used to measure electric current?

choices.A: Attempting to measure resistance using the voltage setting
choices.B: Failing to connect one of the probes to ground
choices.C: Attempting to measure voltage when using the resistance setting
choices.D: Not allowing it to warm up properly

questions.question: Which of the following measurements are made using a multimeter?

What reading indicates that an ohmmeter is connected across a large, discharged capacitor?

choices.D: Alternating between open and short circuit

questions.question: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring in-circuit resistance with an ohmmeter?

choices.A: Ensure that the applied voltages are correct
choices.B: Ensure that the circuit is not powered
choices.C: Ensure that the circuit is grounded
choices.D: Ensure that the circuit is operating at the correct frequency

questions.question: Which of the following is a form of amplitude modulation?

Which type of voice mode is often used for long-distance (weak signal) contacts on the VHF and UHF bands?
Which type of modulation is commonly used for VHF and UHF voice repeaters?
Which of the following types of signal has the narrowest bandwidth?

choices.A: SSB signals are easier to tune in correctly
choices.B: SSB signals are less susceptible to interference

questions.question: What is the approximate bandwidth of a typical single sideband (SSB) voice signal?
What is the approximate bandwidth of a VHF repeater FM voice signal?
What is the approximate bandwidth of AM fast-scan TV transmissions?
What is the approximate bandwidth required to transmit a CW signal?
Which of the following is a disadvantage of FM compared with single sideband?

choices.B: Only one signal can be received at a time
choices.C: FM signals are harder to tune

questions.question: What telemetry information is typically transmitted by satellite beacons?

choices.A: The signal strength of received signals
choices.B: Time of day accurate to plus or minus 1/10 second
choices.C: Health and status of the satellite

questions.question: What is the impact of using excessive effective radiated power on a satellite uplink?

choices.A: Possibility of commanding the satellite to an improper mode
choices.D: Possibility of rebooting the satellite control computer

questions.question: Which of the following are provided by satellite tracking programs?

choices.A: Maps showing the real-time position of the satellite track over Earth
choices.B: The time, azimuth, and elevation of the start, maximum altitude, and end of a pass
choices.C: The apparent frequency of the satellite transmission, including effects of Doppler shift

questions.question: What mode of transmission is commonly used by amateur radio satellites?
What is a satellite beacon?

choices.A: The primary transmit antenna on the satellite
choices.B: An indicator light that shows where to point your antenna
choices.C: A reflective surface on the satellite
choices.D: A transmission from a satellite that contains status information

questions.question: Which of the following are inputs to a satellite tracking program?

choices.C: The last observed time of zero Doppler shift

questions.question: What is Doppler shift in reference to satellite communications?

choices.A: A change in the satellite orbit
choices.B: A mode where the satellite receives signals on one band and transmits on another
choices.C: An observed change in signal frequency caused by relative motion between the satellite and Earth station
choices.D: A special digital communications mode for some satellites

questions.question: What is meant by the statement that a satellite is operating in U/V mode?

choices.A: The satellite uplink is in the 15 meter band and the downlink is in the 10 meter band
choices.B: The satellite uplink is in the 70 centimeter band and the downlink is in the 2 meter band
choices.C: The satellite operates using ultraviolet frequencies
choices.D: The satellite frequencies are usually variable

questions.question: What causes spin fading of satellite signals?

choices.A: Circular polarized noise interference radiated from the sun
choices.B: Rotation of the satellite and its antennas
choices.C: Doppler shift of the received signal
choices.D: Interfering signals within the satellite uplink band

questions.question: What is a LEO satellite?

choices.C: A satellite in low energy operation mode
choices.D: A satellite in low earth orbit

questions.question: Who may receive telemetry from a space station?

choices.B: A licensed radio amateur with a transmitter equipped for interrogating the satellite
choices.C: A licensed radio amateur who has been certified by the protocol developer
choices.D: A licensed radio amateur who has registered for an access code from AMSAT

questions.question: Which of the following is a way to determine whether your satellite uplink power is neither too low nor too high?

choices.A: Check your signal strength report in the telemetry data
choices.B: Listen for distortion on your downlink signal
choices.C: Your signal strength on the downlink should be about the same as the beacon

questions.question: Which of the following methods is used to locate sources of noise interference or jamming?
Which of these items would be useful for a hidden transmitter hunt?
What operating activity involves contacting as many stations as possible during a specified period?
Which of the following is good procedure when contacting another station in a contest?

choices.A: Sign only the last two letters of your call if there are many other stations calling
choices.B: Contact the station twice to be sure that you are in his log
choices.C: Send only the minimum information needed for proper identification and the contest exchange

questions.question: What is a grid locator?

choices.A: A letter-number designator assigned to a geographic location
choices.B: A letter-number designator assigned to an azimuth and elevation
choices.C: An instrument for neutralizing a final amplifier
choices.D: An instrument for radio direction finding

questions.question: How is over the air access to IRLP nodes accomplished?

choices.A: By obtaining a password that is sent via voice to the node
choices.C: By entering the proper internet password

questions.question: What is Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)?

choices.A: A set of rules specifying how to identify your station when linked over the internet to another station
choices.B: A technique employed to “spot” DX stations via the internet
choices.C: A technique for measuring the modulation quality of a transmitter using remote sites monitored via the internet
choices.D: A method of delivering voice communications over the internet using digital techniques

questions.question: What is the Internet Radio Linking Project (IRLP)?

choices.A: A technique to connect amateur radio systems, such as repeaters, via the internet using Voice Over Internet Protocol (VoIP)
choices.B: A system for providing access to websites via amateur radio
choices.C: A system for informing amateurs in real time of the frequency of active DX stations
choices.D: A technique for measuring signal strength of an amateur transmitter via the internet

questions.question: Which of the following protocols enables an amateur station to transmit through a repeater without using a radio to initiate the transmission?
What is required before using the EchoLink system?

choices.B: Purchase a license to use the EchoLink software
choices.C: Register your call sign and provide proof of license

questions.question: What is an amateur radio station that connects other amateur stations to the internet?
Which of the following is a digital communications mode?
What is a “talkgroup” on a DMR repeater?

choices.A: A group of operators sharing common interests
choices.B: A way for groups of users to share a channel at different times without hearing other users on the channel
choices.C: A protocol that increases the signal-to-noise ratio when multiple repeaters are linked together
choices.D: A net that meets at a specified time

questions.question: What kind of data can be transmitted by APRS?
What type of transmission is indicated by the term "NTSC?"

choices.A: A Normal Transmission mode in Static Circuit
choices.B: A special mode for satellite uplink
choices.C: An analog fast-scan color TV signal
choices.D: A frame compression scheme for TV signals

questions.question: Which of the following is an application of APRS?

choices.A: Providing real-time tactical digital communications in conjunction with a map showing the locations of stations
choices.B: Showing automatically the number of packets transmitted via PACTOR during a specific time interval
choices.C: Providing voice over internet connection between repeaters
choices.D: Providing information on the number of stations signed into a repeater

questions.question: What does the abbreviation "PSK" mean?
Which of the following describes DMR?

choices.A: A technique for time-multiplexing two digital voice signals on a single 12.5 kHz repeater channel
choices.B: An automatic position tracking mode for FM mobiles communicating through repeaters
choices.C: An automatic computer logging technique for hands-off logging when communicating while operating a vehicle
choices.D: A digital technique for transmitting on two repeater inputs simultaneously for automatic error correction

questions.question: Which of the following is included in packet radio transmissions?

choices.A: A check sum that permits error detection
choices.B: A header that contains the call sign of the station to which the information is being sent
choices.C: Automatic repeat request in case of error

questions.question: What is CW?

choices.B: A digital mode used primarily on 2 meter FM
choices.D: Another name for a Morse code transmission

questions.question: Which of the following operating activities is supported by digital mode software in the WSJT-X software suite?
What is an ARQ transmission system?

choices.A: A special transmission format limited to video signals
choices.B: A system used to encrypt command signals to an amateur radio satellite
choices.C: An error correction method in which the receiving station detects errors and sends a request for retransmission
choices.D: A method of compressing data using autonomous reiterative Q codes prior to final encoding

questions.question: Which of the following best describes an amateur radio mesh network?

choices.A: An amateur-radio based data network using commercial Wi-Fi equipment with modified firmware
choices.B: A wide-bandwidth digital voice mode employing DMR protocols
choices.C: A satellite communications network using modified commercial satellite TV hardware
choices.D: An internet linking protocol used to network repeaters

questions.question: What is FT8?

choices.B: A digital mode capable of low signal-to-noise operation
choices.C: An eight channel multiplex mode for FM repeaters
choices.D: A digital slow-scan TV mode with forward error correction and automatic color compensation

questions.question: What is a beam antenna?

choices.A: An antenna built from aluminum I-beams
choices.B: An omnidirectional antenna invented by Clarence Beam
choices.C: An antenna that concentrates signals in one direction
choices.D: An antenna that reverses the phase of received signals

questions.question: Which of the following describes a type of antenna loading?

choices.A: Electrically lengthening by inserting inductors in radiating elements
choices.B: Inserting a resistor in the radiating portion of the antenna to make it resonant
choices.C: Installing a spring in the base of a mobile vertical antenna to make it more flexible
choices.D: Strengthening the radiating elements of a beam antenna to better resist wind damage

questions.question: Which of the following describes a simple dipole oriented parallel to Earth's surface?
What is a disadvantage of the short, flexible antenna supplied with most handheld radio transceivers, compared to a full-sized quarter-wave antenna?

choices.B: It transmits only circularly polarized signals

questions.question: Which of the following increases the resonant frequency of a dipole antenna?

choices.B: Inserting coils in series with radiating wires
choices.D: Adding capacitive loading to the ends of the radiating wires

questions.question: Which of the following types of antenna offers the greatest gain?
What is a disadvantage of using a handheld VHF transceiver with a flexible antenna inside a vehicle?

choices.A: Signal strength is reduced due to the shielding effect of the vehicle
choices.B: The bandwidth of the antenna will decrease, increasing SWR
choices.C: The SWR might decrease, decreasing the signal strength

questions.question: What is the approximate length, in inches, of a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna for 146 MHz?
What is the approximate length, in inches, of a half-wavelength 6 meter dipole antenna?
In which direction does a half-wave dipole antenna radiate the strongest signal?

choices.B: Off the ends of the antenna
choices.C: In the direction of the feed line

questions.question: What is antenna gain?

choices.A: The additional power that is added to the transmitter power
choices.B: The additional power that is required in the antenna when transmitting on a higher frequency
choices.C: The increase in signal strength in a specified direction compared to a reference antenna
choices.D: The increase in impedance on receive or transmit compared to a reference antenna

questions.question: What is an advantage of a 5/8 wavelength whip antenna for VHF or UHF mobile service?

choices.A: It has more gain than a 1/4-wavelength antenna
choices.B: It radiates at a very high angle
choices.C: It eliminates distortion caused by reflected signals
choices.D: It has 10 times the power gain of a 1/4 wavelength whip

questions.question: What is a benefit of low SWR?
What is the most common impedance of coaxial cables used in amateur radio?
Why is coaxial cable the most common feed line for amateur radio antenna systems?

choices.A: It is easy to use and requires few special installation considerations
choices.B: It has less loss than any other type of feed line
choices.C: It can handle more power than any other type of feed line
choices.D: It is less expensive than any other type of feed line

questions.question: What is the major function of an antenna tuner (antenna coupler)?

choices.A: It matches the antenna system impedance to the transceiver's output impedance
choices.B: It helps a receiver automatically tune in weak stations
choices.C: It allows an antenna to be used on both transmit and receive
choices.D: It automatically selects the proper antenna for the frequency band being used

questions.question: What happens as the frequency of a signal in coaxial cable is increased?
Which of the following RF connector types is most suitable for frequencies above 400 MHz?
Which of the following is true of PL-259 type coax connectors?

choices.A: They are preferred for microwave operation
choices.C: They are commonly used at HF and VHF frequencies

questions.question: Which of the following is a source of loss in coaxial feed line?
What can cause erratic changes in SWR?

choices.B: Loose connection in the antenna or feed line
choices.D: Overload from a strong local station

questions.question: What is the electrical difference between RG-58 and RG-213 coaxial cable?

choices.A: There is no significant difference between the two types
choices.C: RG-213 cable has less loss at a given frequency
choices.D: RG-58 cable can handle higher power levels

questions.question: Which of the following types of feed line has the lowest loss at VHF and UHF?
What is standing wave ratio (SWR)?

choices.A: A measure of how well a load is matched to a transmission line
choices.B: The ratio of amplifier power output to input
choices.D: An indication of the quality of your station’s ground connection

questions.question: Which of the following is a safety hazard of a 12-volt storage battery?

choices.A: Touching both terminals with the hands can cause electrical shock
choices.B: Shorting the terminals can cause burns, fire, or an explosion
choices.C: RF emissions from a nearby transmitter can cause the electrolyte to emit poison gas

questions.question: What health hazard is presented by electrical current flowing through the body?

choices.A: It may cause injury by heating tissue
choices.B: It may disrupt the electrical functions of cells
choices.C: It may cause involuntary muscle contractions

questions.question: In the United States, what circuit does black wire insulation indicate in a three-wire 120 V cable?
What is the purpose of a fuse in an electrical circuit?

choices.A: To prevent power supply ripple from damaging a component
choices.B: To remove power in case of overload
choices.C: To limit current to prevent shocks

questions.question: Why should a 5-ampere fuse never be replaced with a 20-ampere fuse?

choices.A: The larger fuse would be likely to blow because it is rated for higher current
choices.B: The power supply ripple would greatly increase
choices.C: Excessive current could cause a fire

questions.question: What is a good way to guard against electrical shock at your station?

choices.A: Use three-wire cords and plugs for all AC powered equipment
choices.B: Connect all AC powered station equipment to a common safety ground
choices.C: Install mechanical interlocks in high-voltage circuits

questions.question: Where should a lightning arrester be installed in a coaxial feed line?

choices.A: At the output connector of a transceiver
choices.C: At the ac power service panel
choices.D: On a grounded panel near where feed lines enter the building

questions.question: Where should a fuse or circuit breaker be installed in a 120V AC power circuit?

choices.A: In series with the hot conductor only
choices.B: In series with the hot and neutral conductors
choices.C: In parallel with the hot conductor only
choices.D: In parallel with the hot and neutral conductors

questions.question: What should be done to all external ground rods or earth connections?

choices.A: Waterproof them with silicone caulk or electrical tape
choices.B: Keep them as far apart as possible
choices.C: Bond them together with heavy wire or conductive strap
choices.D: Tune them for resonance on the lowest frequency of operation

questions.question: What hazard is caused by charging or discharging a battery too quickly?
What hazard exists in a power supply immediately after turning it off?

choices.A: Circulating currents in the dc filter
choices.B: Leakage flux in the power transformer

questions.question: Which of the following precautions should be taken when measuring high voltages with a voltmeter?

choices.A: Ensure that the voltmeter has very low impedance
choices.B: Ensure that the voltmeter and leads are rated for use at the voltages to be measured
choices.C: Ensure that the circuit is grounded through the voltmeter
choices.D: Ensure that the voltmeter is set to the correct frequency

sections.section_title: Safety and Installation Principles for Towers

questions.question: Which of the following is good practice when installing ground wires on a tower for lightning protection?

choices.A: Put a drip loop in the ground connection to prevent water damage to the ground system
choices.B: Make sure all ground wire bends are right angles
choices.C: Ensure that connections are short and direct

questions.question: What is required when climbing an antenna tower?

choices.A: Have sufficient training on safe tower climbing techniques
choices.B: Use appropriate tie-off to the tower at all times
choices.C: Always wear an approved climbing harness

questions.question: Under what circumstances is it safe to climb a tower without a helper or observer?

choices.A: When no electrical work is being performed
choices.B: When no mechanical work is being performed
choices.C: When the work being done is not more than 20 feet above the ground

questions.question: Which of the following is an important safety precaution to observe when putting up an antenna tower?

choices.A: Wear a ground strap connected to your wrist at all times
choices.B: Insulate the base of the tower to avoid lightning strikes
choices.C: Look for and stay clear of any overhead electrical wires

questions.question: What is the purpose of a safety wire through a turnbuckle used to tension guy lines?

choices.A: Secure the guy line if the turnbuckle breaks
choices.B: Prevent loosening of the turnbuckle from vibration
choices.C: Provide a ground path for lightning strikes
choices.D: Provide an ability to measure for proper tensioning

questions.question: What is the minimum safe distance from a power line to allow when installing an antenna?

choices.A: Add the height of the antenna to the height of the power line and multiply by a factor of 1.5
choices.B: The height of the power line above ground
choices.D: Enough so that if the antenna falls, no part of it can come closer than 10 feet to the power wires

questions.question: Which of the following is an important safety rule to remember when using a crank-up tower?

choices.A: This type of tower must never be painted
choices.B: This type of tower must never be grounded
choices.C: This type of tower must not be climbed unless it is retracted, or mechanical safety locking devices have been installed

questions.question: Which is a proper grounding method for a tower?

choices.A: A single four-foot ground rod, driven into the ground no more than 12 inches from the base
choices.B: A ferrite-core RF choke connected between the tower and ground
choices.C: A connection between the tower base and a cold water pipe
choices.D: Separate eight-foot ground rods for each tower leg, bonded to the tower and each other

questions.question: Why should you avoid attaching an antenna to a utility pole?

choices.A: The antenna will not work properly because of induced voltages
choices.B: The 60 Hz radiations from the feed line may increase the SWR
choices.C: The antenna could contact high-voltage power lines

questions.question: Which of the following is true when installing grounding conductors used for lightning protection?

choices.B: Wires must be carefully routed with precise right-angle bends

questions.question: Which of the following establishes grounding requirements for an amateur radio tower or antenna?
What type of radiation are radio signals?
At which of the following frequencies does maximum permissible exposure have the lowest value?
How does the allowable power density for RF safety change if duty cycle changes from 100 percent to 50 percent?

choices.A: It increases by a factor of 3
choices.C: It increases by a factor of 2
choices.D: There is no adjustment allowed for lower duty cycle

questions.question: What factors affect the RF exposure of people near an amateur station antenna?

choices.A: Frequency and power level of the RF field
choices.B: Distance from the antenna to a person

questions.question: Why do exposure limits vary with frequency?

choices.A: Lower frequency RF fields have more energy than higher frequency fields
choices.B: Lower frequency RF fields do not penetrate the human body
choices.C: Higher frequency RF fields are transient in nature
choices.D: The human body absorbs more RF energy at some frequencies than at others

questions.question: Which of the following is an acceptable method to determine whether your station complies with FCC RF exposure regulations?

choices.A: By calculation based on FCC OET Bulletin 65
choices.B: By calculation based on computer modeling
choices.C: By measurement of field strength using calibrated equipment

questions.question: What hazard is created by touching an antenna during a transmission?
Which of the following actions can reduce exposure to RF radiation?
How can you make sure your station stays in compliance with RF safety regulations?

choices.A: By informing the FCC of any changes made in your station
choices.B: By re-evaluating the station whenever an item in the transmitter or antenna system is changed
choices.C: By making sure your antennas have low SWR

questions.question: Why is duty cycle one of the factors used to determine safe RF radiation exposure levels?

choices.A: It affects the average exposure to radiation
choices.B: It affects the peak exposure to radiation
choices.C: It takes into account the antenna feed line loss
choices.D: It takes into account the thermal effects of the final amplifier

questions.question: What is the definition of duty cycle during the averaging time for RF exposure?

choices.A: The difference between the lowest power output and the highest power output of a transmitter
choices.B: The difference between the PEP and average power output of a transmitter
choices.C: The percentage of time that a transmitter is transmitting
choices.D: The percentage of time that a transmitter is not transmitting

questions.question: How does RF radiation differ from ionizing radiation (radioactivity)?

choices.A: RF radiation does not have sufficient energy to cause chemical changes in cells and damage DNA
choices.B: RF radiation can only be detected with an RF dosimeter
choices.C: RF radiation is limited in range to a few feet

questions.question: Who is responsible for ensuring that no person is exposed to RF energy above the FCC exposure limits?

choices.C: Anyone who is near an antenna
